title: Liam Williams webchat at MIF âÂ as it happened | Stage | The Guardian
summary: over and out ! thanks for all your questions .
'i find it hard to write comedy that does n't come from a pessimistic miserable starting point '
'like all self-important middle class hipsters , i find a lot about eastern religions interesting '
'i have a very sentimental , mawkish and delicate heart '
'i find it far too depressing to google myself '
'it 's galling to see the austerity approach becoming normal '
'occupy : partly there was a girl i fancied who was involved '

documents.title: over and out ! thanks for all your questions .
text: guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 3:15pm thanks for all your questions .
the producer of the manchester international festival is sat behind me , poking me with a pen , asking me to promote the invisible dot cabaret , which is a the pavilion theatre on thursday .
scottishake asks : why is nobody asking you any questions ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 3:14pm the joke 's on you , pal .
showmaster says : how 's the leg ?
will you be fit to challenge for a starting place for wales v uruguay ?
what ?
wrong liam williams ?
he can fuck off then .
coming round here pretending to be someone important.- ) guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 3:12pm lol .
jimmybreeeze wonders : do you get nervous on stage ?
any tips on conquering fear of the audience ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 3:12pm well , i used to drink to deal with the nerves .
i was on a bus a few weeks ago and some girls got on drinking wine and being rowdy .
they saw me and one of them said , we 've seen you do comedy a few times .
then there was a long pause .
during which i was waiting for her to follow up with a simple compliment .
but the pause continued , until she said : one piece of constructive criticism , you always seem too drunk .
and i now no longer drink before going on stage , and i 'm better as a consequence i think .
so if that girl is reading , then thanks .
i deal with the nerves more directly , rather than trying to mask the feeling .
you conquer the fear by being nervous to an extent , because that gives it an energy , and a sense of occasion .
but i 'll quote an old platitude my pe teacher mr jenkins used to say every single day at school : prior preparation prevents panic .

documents.title: 'i find it hard to write comedy that does n't come from a pessimistic miserable starting point '
text: molly stewart asks : is there a kind of comedy that you particularly enjoy watching ( or a comedian who is doing something you really like ) , that is something you think you could maybe never do ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 3:08pm yes - i find it hard to write comedy that does n't come from a pessimistic miserable starting point .

also i read brian logan 's article the other day , asking whether in its individualism and egotism , if standup is an inherently right-wing art form , and the antidote to that is the interactive , clown-inspired comedy of the likes of dr brown and beard who i mentioned earlier .
i get very nervous about getting the audience involved , which is a shame .
and probably reveals me to be a selfish conservative .
socialistnotnulabour would like to know : you do n't sound like you 're from leeds .
why 's that ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 3:06pm people keep asking me if i 'm welsh .
i 've lived down south for about five years , and my dad is from essex , so it 's something of a hybrid accent now .
scottgough asks : will you show at edinburgh this year involve walking miles in the rain again ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 3:05pm the venue is the three sisters pub , which is more central than last year 's , though it depends on where you 're walking from .
it probably will be raining though .
jacksbackandangry asks : have you improved since your appearance on russel howard ?

i had n't heard of you and that was the only clip on youtube i could find t'was a trifle underwhelming your sarcasm came across as contented and cynical from a position of comfort i wanted anger and the spitting of absurdities by turning the audience inside out to look at their smug assumptions anew .
promising , though for me i did n't feel empathy with your narrative it was just a bit too middle class well educated clever .

guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 3:05pm i do appreciate this person taking the time to watch the set , and think about why they did n't like it , which is more than you sometimes get from people .
it is definitely an anxiety for me , feeling more and more entrenched within a middle class privileged bracket , and i share the criticism of that comment .
i do n't really know what i can do to overcome that educated middle class veneer , but i do n't want to come across as smug and contented .
i 'll keep working on it .

documents.title: 'like all self-important middle class hipsters , i find a lot about eastern religions interesting '
text: thedailybumbler would like to know : if you founded your own religion , what would be the main tenets ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 3:01pm i 'd have to say i ca n't even begin to countenance the idea of becoming religious .
although i admire a lot about , for example , russell brand 's world view .
the spiritual side of it just gets lost on me .
i think you can believe in change and progress for humankind without it having a religious dimension .

like all self-important middle class hipsters , i find a lot about eastern religions interesting , and i enjoyed joseph campbell 's book the hero of a thousand faces but more about what it teaches about story , rather than religion .
ozufan asks : i 've just been given a mindfulness cd as part of a stroke recovery programme .
unfortunately i ca n't take it seriously , partly because of your show last year but mainly it 's inherent silliness .
what would you recommend for relaxation ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:59pm swimming .
it feels quite otherworldly down there .
long walks , ideally in bleak urban landscapes , or bleak rural landscapes .
and sleaford mods .
josholdham asks : was there ever a recording of capitalism made that you would put on youtube ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:58pm we 're gon na record all three of my shows this autumn .
the invisible dot have their arcane methods of distribution - keep an eye on their website .

documents.title: 'i have a very sentimental , mawkish and delicate heart '
text: monolithblack would like to know : did i hear sleaford mods as your walk on music on this tour ?
are they amongst your fave bands ?
who elso do you like ?
also my housemate is a gay man and he wants to have sex with you , have you ever considered trying that ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:57pm yes , they are .
i saw them in london a few months ago and i would n't be surprised if i turned my standup set into a two man post-punk electronic rant outfit .
i have eclectic taste but more in the sort of uniformed youtube browsing way , rather than connoisseurship .
i 've been listening to a girl called no name gypsy , who i heard on chance the rapper 's single ; i also like the staves , because i have a very sentimental , mawkish and delicate heart .
i have considered it , but that 's as far as it 's gone .
and if i did , it probably would n't be with the housemate of somebody on a comments board , at least without him taking me to pizza express or something similar .
monsoonmoon asks : which other comedians / performers do you admire and who has influenced your style ?

guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:54pm just to reel off a dispassionate list : peter cook , monty python , and the individual work of its members , armando iannucci , chris morris , caroline aherne , lee and herring , daniel kitson , tim key , louis ck , woody allen - but i find it hard to watch his stuff now - there must be loads more .

in terms of new people , the guys i do sheeps with , darren johnson and al roberts , jamie demetriou , tash demetriou , ellie white , claudia o'doherty , a double act called beard who i think are going to do really well at edinburgh this year .
far too many more to mention .
james acaster .
the newer people i 'd say are people i admire , and have worked with , so i feel a connection with .
the first list are people i both admire and feel influenced by .
preet dhanoa asks : do you have a favourite american comedian and why ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:50pm probably louis ck .

i do n't want to rhapsodise too much , but he manages the thing that was discussed earlier , of being funny but also having heart and substance and depth , and also his tv show louie again , according with something we discussed earlier , is really idiosyncratic and unconventional .
and unspoiled by having a big creative team , because he does everything himself pretty much .
the stuff i like the most is the stuff that seems borne from a single vision , one person 's way of seeing the world , and not a modish formula .

documents.title: 'i find it far too depressing to google myself '
text: londonidiot wonders : how do you find the time to play international rugby for wales as well as being a comedian ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:48pm not forgetting being a fairly promising semi-professional boxer , as my self-googling has revealed .
but because of the success of liam williams the rugby player , i find it far too depressing to google myself , which is probably a good thing .
thesleeper would like to know : will there ever be a boy born who can swim faster than a shark ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:47pm i 'm struggling to think of a witty response to this , except to say yes , i have seen the office .
i think i 've rewatched it about five times this year alone .
i think my love for it has become so deep and absolute that i 'm beyond rationalising it , like the love you feel at the end of a long and satisfying marriage .
sidebar - i 'm not looking forward to the brent film .
because the bits that they 've done already are just in a different world from the office , it 's ricky gervais doing a kind of pointless rehash of a brilliant character .
marcus hoffman asks : do you think they should bring back the krypton factor ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:45pm no , but i think they should bring back big break .
maybe me as host .
yes , i do have a hot tv idea
kirstyg asks : what is the hardest thing about being a stand-up ?
how long did it take you to develop your own voice/ style ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:44pm the comments on the internet can be hard to take .
people visibly finding you really unfunny , from the stage , because you 're causing them to suffer and that feels bad .
and it 's very easy to internalise the projected hatred you get from audiences .
the solution is to just shut down a bit emotionally .
that 's a useful rule of thumb for life anyway , i think .

it 's very difficult to put a definitive number on it - it was probably about three years of pretty thankless scrabbling around on the open mike circuit before i really felt like i knew what i was doing .
doing it , thinking about it all the time , watching stuff .

documents.title: 'it 's galling to see the austerity approach becoming normal '
text: owain doherty asks : seeing as the conservative party are intent on cutting by 20 percent across the board , and looking to block future governments from lending to any point of deficit at all , should .
we be campaigning to make sure that all of the conservative party members also have similar sanctions in place ?
no overdrafts , mortgages , loans or finance deals .

and 20 percent cut off all clothing items , to go into material bins , 20 percent of their holidays ruined by professional holiday ruiners , 20 percent of their over privilaged estates to be turned into dog toilets and waste dumps , 20 percent of each meal they order to be given away to homeless and 20 percent of their savings at home or abroad to be transferred to the nhs ?

guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:41pm their point is that people should be paying less tax anyway , so they 'd see their freedom from the consequences of welfare cuts as being absolutely fine .
i was reading a piece in the guardian , by matthew d'ancona , that was fairly pro-osborne , and it was really galling stuff - to see the austerity approach becoming standard and normal .
it 's hard to see it changing .
id6688805 wonders : can you be an outsider comedian and yet also appear in the guardian ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:38pm i think the guardian billed me as an 'outsider comedian ' and it depends what you consider to be outside of .
i am a kind of happy , card-carrying guardian-reading wanker , and read the guide every week when i was a kid and thought it was cool - i 'm not embarrassed to be that .
it 's not very clear cut , the lines in comedy .
just looking at the fringe , because of the free fringe , anyone can do a thing and if it captures the imagination those acts can become bigger and more widely known .
there are people at the fringe who would watch me and find it really lame or unexciting , and nowhere near radical or experimental enough - and that does n't bother me that much .

documents.title: 'occupy : partly there was a girl i fancied who was involved '
text: clareyesno asks : why is the occupy cause important and why did you get involved ?
what should comedians be raging against these days , and is it hard to be funny about social injustice , politics etc ?

guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:35pm you ca n't be too prescriptive about what people should be raging against , but maybe people should be raging more for whatever it is they do believe in .

i 'd say yes , in a way it 's hard to be funny about politics , because especially amongst younger comedians , any sort of sincere or emotive expression of opinion is lame , and you get probably more comedy taking the piss out of political comedy that you get political comedy .
or perhaps that 's just amongst my 'cool ' corner of the circuit .
occupy : partly there was a girl i fancied who was involved .

also , and this is probably quite a familiar and unsurprising answer , but i felt like the means of political engagement as they exist in this country are really frustrating and it 's very hard to convey or feel like you 're making any contribution to causes you believe in , just by voting once every five years .
occupy seemed like a good way to demonstrate and argue and make the point that big reforms and big changes are possible .

however i think that a lot of people who are involved in occupy and similar causes feel a bit cowed and are uncertain what to do next - but there are exciting progressive groups , like the people 's assembly for example .

a lot of it seems to be happening spontaneously and naturally anyway - like the focus e15 housing operation , and groups like occupy , and also really simple more quotidian things like community gardens and local housing groups .
stewwalls would like to know : have you got any dynamite tv ideas ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:31pm yeah , but i 'm not going to waste them on here .
i think it 's getting easier to work up ideas .

i literally had an idea the other day , where i found myself in a situation and thought it would be interesting for tv - with prolonged consideration of a particular form , the ideas start coming more easily .
i have already written a tv script , which was commissioned by channel 4 - i went quite a long way through the process , but it was turned down .
so that put me off for a while .
i might try again , fail better - is that the phrase ?
high maintenance is something i 've found recently that i find inspiring - it 's pretty homespun , and very good .
i 'm interested in things that sidestep big production departments , more homemade stuff .

documents.title: 'david foster wallace made me feel less of a dismal failure '
text: id384208 wonders : how would you describe your writing process ?
how do you find being a low energy/introverted comedian in an extroverted industry ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:27pm well , i try and be very disciplined and regimented at the moment .
when i first started to write standup and other things , i 'd sit down with five hours ahead of me , and fritter them away on the internet .

and the i read the david foster wallace biography , and he said in that that he was happy if he wrote three hours of writing a day , and that made me feel that yeah , i was less of a dismal failure if i did n't work for eight hours a day .

i watched a lot of videos about how to write , and there was a john cleese one in which he said he finds it hard to concentrate for more than 90 minutes , and the 90 minute mark is a sweet spot for creativity .
so i really try and do two 90 minute sessions a day .
it depends what i 'm writing too .

now i 'm working on a radio series , which tends to be head over the keyboard bashing away - maybe bashing away is n't the right phrase¦ whereas standup requires a lot more imaginative work where you 're walking around trying to do routines in your head , and some of it never even gets written down .
i think i have to be very project-orientated , , which is a horrible phrase , but i ca n't sit down and have an idea .
i need to know what form it 's going to be , whether on stage or on air .
the ideas tend to be a product of working out anxieties in my head , things that keep returning to my head and make me feel awkward in some way , that 's the stuff i latch onto .
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:28pm it 's quite easy to be introverted , because of my relative novelty .

i was just five minutes ago doing my warmup for this mif show , and the room was empty except from a few technicians , and no-one was laughing - it really struck me how boring my voice is if there 's no energy it 's reacting against .

documents.title: 'you 're never fully comfortable '
text: madskraleine asks : i want to ask when you felt you found your voice ' and how did you square having political/potentially unfunny ' elements to your set when you first started out in stand-up ?
did you find that you had to overcompensate with other jokes to win a crowd and that now you have success it 's allowed you more freedom to write the material that you want ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:22pm i would say that it 's not the case that i 've found my voice .
there 's a good simon munnery quote , which is that show is never finished , just abandoned , and it 's the same with your artistic voice , i 'd say .
you 're never fully comfortable .
there are definitely a couple of years where i was doing stuff that i was n't all that proud of , that would go down well .
quite lame gags that did n't add much bite .
but i think that it 's just absolutely necessary that you can hold a crowd , and a few entertaining gags buys you a bit more licence to say what you really feel .
also the two perhaps should n't be mutually exclusive .
that 's what i find exciting now : to write stuff that has substance , but is also just funny .
kicking things off , mrman21 asks : which canned lager do you consider to be your favourite ?
guardian contributor liamwilliams1 06 july 2015 2:18pm i 've been thinking about this , because i made a bit of a fetish for talking about specific brands of lager on stage .
it 's become a bit of a schtick .
but i 've been questioning whether i should be promoting big brands .
so i should probably say something like camden hells , a small , local hipster brand .
that , or heineken .

documents.title: liam williams is in the house ( /empty office space )
text: here he is , ready to answer your questions .
ready to answer your questions¦ liam williams .
beaumont-thomas

documents.title: post your questions for liam williams
text: at the heart of liam williams 's comedy is the sus that everything is a bit rubbish , whether it 's pop culture , social inequality , or ultimately his own life .
but he 's no insufferable sad-sack : his lacerations of himself and others reflect a desire to really feel and truly live .
this impassioned and very funny material , about anything from porn to mindfulness , won him a nomination as best newcomer at last year 's edinburgh festival .
he 's been around for a while though , with his surreal sketch trio sheeps first hitting the fringe in 2010 .
he also played host at the recent comedy gigs in parliament square , held by the occupy movement as part of their festival of democracy .
next up is a stint at manchester international festival alongside his peers from comedy venue the invisible dot , doing a nightly cabaret .
he 'll join us live from the festival to answer your questions in a webchat , from 2.15pm onwards on monday 6 july post your questions in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: He has a delicate heart', was made to feel less of a failure by reading David Foster Wallace and has plenty to say about austerity Britain the outsider comedian answered your questions live from Manchester international festival.
